awd_titl_txt: Combining metabolic engineering and synthetic biology to engineer natural product synthesis in oleaginous yeast
awd_abstract_narration:
Plants produce chemicals with medicinal properties. Isolating plant natural products (PNPs) from native sources is difficult due to low concentrations. Chemical synthesis is often not economical because of the structural complexity of PNPs. This project will modify yeast to produce a PNP with anti-cancer properties. This molecule represents a class of PNPs with therapeutic value. If yeast can produce high concentrations of PNPs, these drugs could become more affordable. Outreach activities are also planned. Research opportunities will be offered to minority undergraduates. Teaching demonstrations and science fair presentations will be made in Baltimore and the DC area. The goal of these efforts will be to recruit female high school students and underrepresented minorities to pursue STEM careers. 

To improve the cost-competitiveness of PNP production, the project will address cofactor balance (ATP, NADPH, CoASH et al) and maximize the carbon flow and electron reduction efficiency towards the target pathway. This interdisciplinary approach combines genetic engineering, gene regulation, adaptive lab evolution, tolerance phenotyping, metabolic profiling, and cellular compartmentalization engineering. Biochemical and genetic strategies will abolish HMG-CoA pathway negative feedback control, improve metabolite trafficking, and overexpress plant P450 enzymes.  These efforts should improve pathway efficiency and diversify the chemical structure of PNPs. Our strategy will target pathway yield and the total cost of manufacturing. The goal is to build a cost-competitive cyclic triterpenoids biomanufacturing platform with significantly reduced manufacturing cost. This project will provide a testbed for engineering Y. lipolytica and expanding nature's capacity to produce complex PNPs with pharmaceutical values for clinical trials and treating emerging diseases.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated how cells ensure the accuracy of protein synthesis—the precise translation of genetic information from mRNA into proteins. Accuracy is essential because even a single incorrect amino acid can compromise a protein’s structure and function. During translation, the ribosome reads mRNA codons—three-nucleotide sequences—each specifying a particular amino acid. tRNAs deliver these amino acids to the ribosome by pairing their anticodon sequences with the mRNA codons. For translation to be accurate, the ribosome must accept only the correct (cognate) tRNA that perfectly matches each codon. Misreading occurs when a near-cognate tRNA, with a similar but imperfect match, is mistakenly accepted and its amino acid incorporated into the growing protein.

To monitor these errors in living cells, our lab developed a set of reporter constructs. These constructs are based on genes that encode enzymes with an incorrect amino acid at their active site. This mutation renders the enzymes mostly inactive. However, if a misreading event restores the correct amino acid during translation, the enzyme regains activity. By measuring the activity of the mutant enzyme relative to the wild type, we quantify the frequency of misreading. This system provides a sensitive and specific way to assess translational accuracy under various genetic and physiological conditions.

In the first part of the project, we investigated how cellular signaling influences ribosomal fidelity. We uncovered a mechanism involving serine/threonine kinases—enzymes that phosphorylate proteins on serine or threonine residues. A key target is ribosomal protein uS5, which is phosphorylated at serine 176. Our work suggested that this modification promotes the formation of a non-covalent salt bridge between uS5 and the adjacent protein uS4. Each of these proteins plays a role in maintaining decoding accuracy. The energy required to disrupt the protein interface between them is thought to help the ribosome reject near-cognate tRNAs. We believe that phosphorylation, by strengthening the interaction, increases this energetic barrier and thereby enhances translation accuracy.

We identified two kinases, Ctk1 and Ypk2, as key regulators in this process. Deleting either gene significantly increased translation error rates, consistent with a role in promoting uS5 phosphorylation. To further clarify their roles, we used inhibitors of TORC1 and Pkc1. Inhibiting these kinases reversed the high error rates in ctk1Δ cells but not in ypk2Δ cells, suggesting that Ypk2 acts downstream of TORC1 directly or indirectly on uS5. This kinase-controlled pathway for translation accuracy operates not only in Saccharomyces cerevisiae, where we first discovered it. We have evidence for a similar pathway in mammalian cells, including humans. Genomic comparisons show that the components of this pathway are conserved across most multicellular eukaryotes, suggesting it is a widely shared mechanism for ensuring accurate protein synthesis.

The second part of the project explores how tRNAs contribute to accuracy. tRNAs must fold into specific three-dimensional shapes to function properly within the ribosome. After transcription, tRNAs undergo chemical modifications at specific positions—a process known as post-transcriptional modification. These modifications are traditionally thought to stabilize tRNA structure and prevent degradation. However, we hypothesize that they also fine-tune decoding accuracy.

To test this, we deleted genes encoding enzymes that modify a group of tRNAs known to affect translation fidelity. We found that loss of these modifications did not increase tRNA degradation. Instead, it changed the frequency of translational errors. In many cases, removing specific modifications increased misreading, suggesting that these modifications help prevent near-cognate tRNAs from outcompeting the correct ones. In other cases, misreading decreased. These data suggest that the cell maintains a balance—tuning each tRNA’s activity to maintain consistent fidelity across the entire tRNA pool. These results suggest that tRNA modifications play an active role in regulating decoding accuracy.

Together, these findings reveal two key mechanisms cells used to maintain the accuracy of protein synthesis. First, phosphorylation of ribosomal proteins reinforces structural features of the ribosome’s decoding center, improving its ability to select the correct tRNA. Second, post-transcriptional modifications to tRNAs modulate their performance, preventing misreading by influencing structural stability and competitive behavior. Both systems are highly conserved: phosphorylation-based regulation is widespread among eukaryotes, while tRNA modification is universal across all domains of life.

These discoveries deepen our understanding of how cells control the fidelity of gene expression. By identifying conserved pathways that regulate translation accuracy, this work provides a foundation for further investigation into how these mechanisms are disrupted in disease. Errors in protein synthesis are linked to various disorders, including certain neurodegenerative diseases and cancers. Understanding how cells normally prevent these errors opens the door to exploring new strategies for diagnosis and therapy in conditions where translational fidelity is compromised.
